content.description:
Jug feet, huge handholds, an easier less scary early exit or a taller more exciting exit. Take your pick. Start on the large shelf, move up and right to the apex before topping out, or rock onto the slab early.

 Great for beginners and great for warming up in the tennis shoes or boots.
content.location: This climb starts on the leftside of the Westface of the block.

content.description: Start with the right hand on a low fat-pinch located on the arete, with the left hand a foot lower on a decent gaston also found on the arete. Find a toe and lock-off to some crimp rail features on the face. Come in with the other hand to the rail-feature before a cruxy move up to the sloping arete. Match the arete and figure out how to mantle.
content.protection: 2 or 3 and a spotter. There is a drop-off a few feet behind this boulder, and there is a bit of a cave at the base of the climb.
content.location: This problem starts on the same arete as "Panda Bear" but on the opposite side(Westface) of the boulder.

content.description: This is a great compression climb that squeezes an arete and a few different sidepull features. Start sitting with the left hand on a bucket sidepull just inside the cave, and the right hand on a sidepull edge just below the arete. Pull-on and smack up lefty or righty to a positive hold before busting out left to a far sloping shelf. From here heel-hook and smack up some slopers with an exciting last move to a blind hold.
content.protection: 2 or 3 pads. The landing is flat and safe.
content.location: This climb is on the outside of the small cave/ corridor and climbs the overhanging face and arete of the uphill side of the boulder.

content.description:
Sit start with the left-hand low on the sloping arete and with the right hand on a large undercling feature a few feet right of the arete. Pull on to the wall and slap up the arete a few times before bumping the right hand to another undercling or sidepull. A few tenuous moves gains jugs at the lip of the boulder and an easy topout. 

 Hint: Think Thumb-catch.
content.protection: 2 pads. The landing is a bit uneven and there is a drop off about 5 feet behind this climb, but most of the falls are safe.
content.location: This problem is on the rightside of the downhill arete on the boulder. From this side of the boulder, one can see the uphill side of the Block Boulder.

climbs.name: Life in the Time of COVID

content.description: Sit start with your left hand on a chip and right on a meathook undercling. Pull on and move left up to a good edge, power right out to the sloper and then top out on a series of good holds.
content.protection: A couple of pads, it is a relative lowball but you climb over a two tiered landing, falling between the two tiers could be uncomfortable.
content.location: This is not on the Paperboy Boulder proper. If standing with your back to the the start of Vanilla Twilight, this is the overhanging face you see 15 feet down the hill.

content.description: A one mover starting on a pair of opposing sidepulls. The left hand is a bit of an undercling  and the right hand is the opposite located a few feet to the right. Pull-on and make a hard move to the arete lip then finish on jugs.
content.protection: 1 or 2 pads. don't fall down the hill.
content.location: In between "Panda Bear" and "Burger Bars and Bumper Cars".

content.description: Sit start matched on the large sidepull undercling feature. Figure out some leg trickery and bust a massive move to the hole in the top part of the boulder. Figure out the no-hands knee-bar and float on to the top of the boulder.
content.location: This line is found to the right of the aesthetic arete "Panda Bear".

content.description: This is a large boulder with a handful of solid climbs found on it. This boulder sits on the hill just up from the Block Boulder. This boulder is clearly visible from the backside of the Block Boulder, but approaching it can be a bit tricky.
